THE NEWS LETIE
VOL. XV, NO. 15.
UNDERCLASS MEN ARE READY
The Track and Field Meet on Saturday
to be a Great Success Some
New Features.

AI onager Hering of the 'varSity
track •teams and the captains and
managers of the sophomore and
freshman teams are working hard
to make the annual sophomorefreshman indoor track and field
meet to be held in the University
"cage" next Saturday surpass any
previous interclass meet that has
ver been held at Hopkins.
Owing to the limited seating capacity of the "cage" gallery, the
managers have decided to issue a
certain number of invitations which
will be distributed among the sophomores and freshmen. Only those
who have invitations will be admitted until the meet begins, and
then, if there is any space left,
it will.be a case ot first come first
served.
The old custom of having a silk
'banner as a trophy for the winning
class has been revived. This will be
embroidered with the numerals of
the victorious class and, as an everpresent reminder of its prowess in
track and field athletics, wil repose
on the walls of Levering Hall.
A distinctive feature of this
year's meet will be the relay race.
Although this event will not count
towards the winning of the meet,
it N arousing considerable interest
as an independent affair. The relay
teams will consist of four men, each
of whom will run three laps.
The freshmen will probably be
handicapped by the loss of their
captain who it at present laid up
with the mumps. There is a slight
possibility of his recovering in time
to take part, but his illness will prevent him from appearing at his best
even if he does compete, which is
not likely.
H. E. Catlin, the crack quarterback of the freshman football team
will act as captain during the illness,
of Wells. The freshmen have been
practicing regularly with the 'varsity squad and they will enter
quite a number of men.
Captain Ray, of the sophomores,
is quite optomistic in regard to the
outcome of the meet. He believes
that it will be close, but that the
sophomores will win by a few
points. In Ray, Pieper, and Novak,
thesophomores have some sure point
winners. and many of the other
sophomores' athletes have shown up
well so far in practice.
While the entries in the various
events will not be definitely known
until Thursday, Ray and Catlin
Cotitinued on page 6, col. 3.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 23, 1911.
CONCERT IN EASTON A GREAT
SUCCESS
Musical Clubs Take a Hurried Trip to
the Eastern Shore Town and Make
a Great Hit.

BALTIMORE LACROSSE LEAGUE
FORMED
Schedule for the Coming Season Completed Huck Elected President A
Four Club Circuit to be Formed.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
HARESFOOT CLUB TRYOUT
A Large Number of Candidates Respond
—The Cast To Be Definitely
Settled Next Week.

So many students wishing to
take part in the annual play of the
Haresfoot Club responded Tuesday
night in answer to the call for
candidates issued by N. Williams
Haynes, president of the club, that
two and three candidates had to be
assigned for the time being to each
of the 13 characters of the play.
Henry Edward \Varner, the wellknown local journalist, first president of the American Press
Humorists' Association and veteran
theatrical coach, will definitely
select the cast at the first rehearsal,
to be held some time. next week.
The club has also decided to have
an understudy for each character.
The play to be given is entitled
"What Happened to Jones." The
name will probably be changed, as
the play itself will be altered somewhat. The club is thinking of
offering a prize for the best name
submitted for the play. Several
out-of-town performances will be
given, and some time aiound Easter
the home performance will be given
at Albaugh's for the benefit of the
Homewood fund. Mty alumni
are already greatly interested in
the club and will work hard to
make this year's production a big
success.
Among • the candidates are: N.
W. Haynes, Frederick C. Lee,
Lindsay Rogers, Edward 0. Hulhurt, C. Leland Getz, Donald K.
Belt, Harold B. Hering, T. Brooke
Price, Paul 0. Carter, Edwin L.
Frederick, Alfred M. Randolph,
Mortimer McKeeney, Benjamin
Tappan, George C. Ober, Jr., J.
\Ale Stockett, G. G. Murray, Jr.,
Richard S. McCabe, and J. C. Martin.

The Baltimore Lacrosse League
held a meeting in the trophy room,
on Wednesday, to elect the officers
and make out the schedule for the
coming season.
The following officers were elected to serve for the following year:
President, John G. Hitck, J. H. U.;
Vice-President, George W. Gillett,
J. H. U.; Secretary, Edward Baker,
Mt. Washington; Treasurer, E. S.
Wiley, B. C. C.
The league consists of three
teams: Hopkins Scrubs, Mt. Washington Juniors, and Baltimore City
College. Last year some of the
alumni at Hopkins, who are great
lacrosse enthusiasts, chipped in and
bought a handsome cup for the
winning team; and for second
prize a beautiful banner was bought
by the league. The Mt. Washington Juniors came out first in the
league, and Baltimore City College
second. The league was organized
by William S. Schmeisser about
four years ago. Its purpose is to
build up interest in lacrosse in the
preparatory schools of Baltimore.
The league has made rapid strides
every year and it is hoped before
the season begins to have a fourth
team in the league.

Schmeisser,

Last Friday evening, the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs of the University gave a concert at the Music
Hall, Easton, Maryland, before a
large and fashionable audience.
The concert was greatly enjoyed
by every one, especially the solo
by Mr. Ruth, and "Molly Lee" by
the Instrumental Club. Stollenwerck's medley, as usual, won great
applause.
After the concert the members
of the club attended an informal
dance, given for their benefit by the
young ladies of the town. They
were entertained Friday evening at
the houses of the various patronesses, and returned to the city on
the 9 o'clock train Saturday morning.
Those making the trip were: J.
K. Ulig, H. B. Dornblazer, W. C.
Haupt, S. White, 0. K. Schmeid,

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 23, 1911.

We regret that, owing to the
pressure of his work, Mr. T.
Brooke Price has been compelled to
resign as editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER. He will be much
missed, but we are glad to announce that we may retain him
on the board as a contributing
editor.
Other changes in the board and
new appointments were:
Lindsay Rogers, now managing
editor, to be assistant editor-inchief.
G. T. 0. Hollyday to be assistant
business manager.
George Edwin Dorsey to be
associate editor.

In the course of class work it
sometimes devolves upon us to do
some private reading in books
which are placed on reserved
shelves. The University cannot
supply each man with a copy and
the thirty or forty members of the
class must divide their time so that
each one has an opportunity to do
But prothe required reading.
crastination is an inevitable part of
human nature. The reading is
usually left • undone until a quizz
'is announced and then everyone
makes a rush for the books. At
such a time as this evil traits of
character at once manifest themselves in some students. In an unaccountable manner the books disappear. This is not so serious a
matter when there are five or six
copies on the shelves; but when
the book in question is a rare or
an expensive one it means that one
fellow sits at home and reads the
Look in his leisure time while the
others are frantically searching for
it. Two years ago an incident
occured which may illustrate this.
Some reading was required of a
class in a book which was out of
print and of which the library pos:
sessed only one copy. Shortly before the examination the book disappeared and several weeks later
reappeared in just as mysterious
a manner. Nothing was lost but
all the members of the class except
one were deprived of the use of the
book.
This is not the attitude of a true
university student. We should be
thankful for and appreciate the advantage which we enjoy in being
allowed free access to all books
in the library. Stich opportunities
should not be prostituted to greed
and selfishness, but should be used
so that all may receive the greatest
amount of good.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 23, 1911

:3

THE GYMNASIUM CONTESTS

NEW LACROSSE LISTS POSTED

ARBITRATION SOCIETY MEETS

CHESS TOURNAMENTS

Blues in the Lead—Hinrichs and Reilly
Big Point Winners.

A Different Method of Distributing Practice New Men Show Promise
of Good Work.

Talks Given by Members on Franklin,
Henry IV and Grotius.

Matches to be Arranged with University
of Pennsylvania and University of
Maryland—Freshman-Sophomore Match Probable.

The freshman gymnasium contest started off with a rush this
week. From the outset, both sides
were so enthusiastic that the entrants needed no urging from their
captains to be present. Besides the
ambition to win a medal, each
freshman wanted to do his part
toward breaking the records of last
year's contest. The gymnasium
class had been divided into two
sectfons, corresponding in ability, as
nearly as possible.
The captain .of the Blues is
Ceorge Dorsey; of the Whites,
Stewart White.
On Monday Professor Kistler
decided to open the contest. The
first event was the pull-up. One
point was given for each pull; in
that way every one could add at
least a few points to his side's
score.
Hinrichs (Whites) won first
place with seventeen to his credit.
Bryan (Whites) was second with
sixteen.
The second event was the standing high jump and Hinrichs again
won.
Although the Whites had made
174 point to their 162, in the first
day's work, the Blues determined
to struggle all the harder on Wednesday, caught up and passed the
Whites, much to the latter's
astonishment.
The score now was 215 to 214.
The records are as follows:
Pull-ups—This year, Hinrichs,
17; last year, H. H. Lloyd, 13.
Standing high jump—This year,
Hinrichs, 4 feet 2 inches; last year,
Kuehn, 5 feet 572 inches.
Fence vault—This year, Reilly,
5 feet 9 inches.
Standing broad jump—This year,
Reilly, 8 feet io inches; last year,
Hyland Stewart, 8 feet 9 inches.
Running high jump—This year,
White, 5 feet 72 inch; last year,
Hyland Stewart, 4 feet io% inches.

In spite of the fact that there
was some confusion about the
coaches, the prospects for a championship lacrosse team this year
are unusually bright. In the place
of Charlie Meyer, who was forced
to give up the position of head
coach on account of his graduate
work, Pitts Raleigh has taken
charge of the team. Coach Raleigh
played first defence on the team
last year, and is considered to be
one of the best close defence men
ever produced by Hopkins.
This year's captain, Eddie Hulbert, has adopted different tactics
from those used last year. He is
having the new men come out by
themselves on Wednesdays, instead
of only the best men as last year.
The whole squad is divided into
two sections, one of which practices
on Mondays and Thursdays, and
the other on Tuesdays and Fridays.
It is necessary to have the old men
in the squads, in order to teach the
new men the fine points of stick
work. On Saturdays there is a
scrimmage, which usually lasts for
about thirty-five minutes.
Since the Christmas holidays the
men have been working very hard,
and as a result they begin to show
a great improvement in condition.
The general opinion is that the new
tactics are better than the old, and
great results are expected.
The Tuesday and -Friday squad
consists of Stockett, Schmeisser,
Huck, Hopkins, J. Burgan, Rosenthal, Richardson, Herman,Simpson,
Hinrichs, Wilkens, Niles, Sears,
Makel, Simon, and Belt.
Dr. Abercrombie has permitted
the candidates for the Baltimore
City College lacrosse team the use
of the "cage" on Tuesdays and
Thursdays from three to four
o'clock. Stockett, Huck, and Gillet
are coaching the youngsters, and it
is hoped that under their able instruction they may some day turn
out to be good 'varsity men.
The regular Saturday squad consists of Stockett, Easter, Paulus,
Gail, Wolfe, Gillet, Hopkins, Niles,
Sutton, Huck, Price, Schmeisser,
Sears, Benedict, Everton, Wolman,
Randall, and Bridgman.

The Chess Club is showing that
it is a vital, living organization,
one that has come to stay and which
will add one more to the list of
permanent undergraduate activities.
The captain of the team, W. E.
Pearce, Jr., is in communication
with the chess club of the Univvsity of Pennsylvania and it is likely
that the date of the match will be
about the middle of February. It
is to be a six-board match.
At a meeting of the executive
committee on Friday the challenge
of the City College to the freshman
team was considered. As there is
no freshman team here it was proposed to make up a seven-man team
from the players in the minor tournament to play the City College
team. A committee of one was appointed to confer with the captain
of the City College team and
arrange a date.
Recently.a chess club was formed
at the University of Maryland and
it was expected that the Hopkins
team would receive a challenge from
them. But this challenge has not
come. So the captain of the Hopkins team was instructed to send
a challenge to the University of
Maryland team for an eight-board
match to be played either on the 3d,
4th, or ioth of February. It is
desired to have several matches
before the team goes to Philadelphia to play the strong team of
the Pennsylvania University and so
it is necessary that these matches
be played as soon as possible.
All but five games of the minor
tournament have been played. The
tournament was to have come to a
close on the 21st of January but
the executive committee voted to
extend this time two weeks.
It has been proposed to the freshman and sophomore classes to have
an interclass chess match. Such
a match would add another to the
list of contests between the classes
and would arouse great interest.
This question will be voted on by
both classes this week and the
teams will be chosen as soon as possible.
Junior Banquet Committee.

President Wilmer Ray, of the
sophomore class has appointed the
committee to arrange the annual
class banquet. It consists of C.
Leland Getz, chairman, Emory H.
Niles, C. Ellis Ellicott, and President Ray, ex-officio.

"Good Old Mantuan."

The Classical Club of the Johns
Hopkins University met last evening at 614 N. Howard street, on
invitation of Dr. W.E. Moseley. Dr.
Wilfred Mustard, collegiate professor of Latin, read an interesting
paper on "The Eclogues of Baptista
Mantuanus."
These were ten Latin poems
written in the second half of the
fifteenth century, and first printed
in the year 1498. They were immediately provided with a commentary, by a well-known scholar,
Badius Ascensius ; and for nearly
two hundred years they were very
commonly used, both on the Continent and in England, as a text-book
in schools. And they had a very
considerable influence upon 'European literature of the sixteenth
century.
The author was a Carmelite friar
of Mantua, who afterwards rose to
be general of his order. He was
beatified in 1885. His works were
very popular, and he was hailed
by many of his contemporaries as
a second Virgil. He is often quoted
in Elizabethan writers—for example, in Shakespeare's "Love's
Labours Lost." And his Eclogues
were very frequently imitated, the
most important instance being
Spenser's "Shepherd's Calendar."

The second general meeting of
the Arbitration Society was held
in the Donovan Room Wednesday
afternoon at three o'clock.
President Bobbitt opened the
meeting with a brief review of the
progress which has been made in
interesting the schools and colleges
of the country in the peace movement, and stated that the Arbitration Society at Hopkins, being the
first institution of the kind ever
organized, it would, if successful,
probably serve as a model for
future orgaizations.
Brief talks were then given by
various members of the society on
early labourers toward universal
peace. Mr. Lindsay Rogers discussing Benjamin Franklin, Mr.
J. E. Uhler, Henry of Navarre, and
Mr. J. S. Dickinson, Hugo Grotius.
A motion was carried that henceforth the society hold a general
meeting once every two weeks, and
the president was instructed to appoint a committee of three on programs.

The Speech for .Special Occasions,'
edited by Ella A. Knapp, Ph, D., Associate Professor of Rhetoric in Goucher
College, and John C. French, Ph. D.,
Associate in English in the Johns Hopkins University. The Macmillan Company. Price. $1.10 net.

This volume of occasional speeches, prepared by Professor Knapp
and Dr. French, is intended to supply a need which has come to the
attention of the authors in their
own teaching. It is intended to
afford the college student a collection of the best speeches delivered upon such occasions as are
likely to confront him in his own
career.
Consequently in these
pages we meet none of the timehonored models of forensic or parliamentary eloquence. Henry May
is represented not by the closing
passage of his speech on the Greek
Revolution nor on the Expunging
Resolution, but by a few simple
and courteous words of welcome to
Lafayette. Daniel Webster contributes, not the peroration of the Reply
to Hague, but a humble effort addressed to the Royal Agricultural
Society of England. The collection
is intended not merely as a textbook, but also as a manual for the
general reader, to which he may
turn for assistance when confronted
by that most embarassing of all
requests, the invitation to make a
speech. For this purpose the selections are classified according to
the nature of the occasion upon
which they were delivered. Thus
there are "Speeches in Behalf of
a Cause," "Speeches of a President," "Speeches of Welcome,"
"Speeches of Farewell," etc.
The selections, which were for
the most part chosen by Professor
Knapp are, on the whole, quite
appropriate. Because of the very
nature of the book, there are but
few from the works of the world's
great orators and most are taken
from the sincere and informal utterances of scholars and statesmen of
the past half century—men like
Bancroft, Emerson, Bryant, Root,
and Gildersleeve. It might seem,
therefore, a matter for curiosity
how a quaint and time-mellowed
,peech of Queen Elizabeth came to
find its way into such company.
Dr. French contributes an introduction of thirty-three pages, in
which he sets forth briefly and concisely the principles following
which a speech may be most effectivelr composed and delivered.

He says that the peace advocates

but a foreign war as well; a war not

Not content with outlining his

half, of the work which he

Governmental partnership in

Each reader will have to accept

the whole question is whether the

settlement of international differences without resort to the arbitrament of the sword is another

THE •NEWS-LETTER,- JANUARY 23, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER

is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.
I notice that the football management has scheduled a game with the
Navy on October 7th. Permit me
to register a protest against this apparent foolhardiness. Our team
never reaches the height of its capability until the season is half completed; the late opening of the University, the consequent lateness of
beginning of practice, the impossibility of getting out the Medical
School men in .the first weeks, all
contribute to make our team at this
time a mere shadow of what it will
become later. By hard work we
have reached the standard of big
college teams. We have been allowed an opportunity to show if we
can hold to this standard. The
Navy has said: "You have boasted
so much that we'll give you a
chance. Let's see what you can
do." In return, we shall play them
with practically the weakest team
that we can put on the field. Nothing will contribute so surely to send
us back to the rank of small colleges
as a failure to make a good showing
against the Navy. And who can be
idiotic enough to claim that we
shall make a good showing? In our
first game last year we were tied
by the Maryland Agricultural College; in our first game this year
what will not the Navy do to us?
Our pretensions to higher standing
will become a pretense. Mr.- Yellott
will grin for a whole week. We
shall not have the opportunity to do
justice to ourselves that a later
game would afford.
INDIGNATION PERSONIPIED.
The Tocqueville Medal.

HULLABALOO BOARD ORGANIZES
-Rosenthal Elected Editor-in-Chief—Belt
and Makel Business- Managers.

The question of publishing the
year book for 1911, the Hullabaloo,
has at last been settled. Owing to
the failure of the junior class to
publish it last year, there was a
great deal of controversy as to who
should publish it this year, the present junior class or the senior class.
It was finally decided to get out a
joint book, each class choosing six
representatives. The senior class
elected: Rosenthal, Tappan, Makel,
Stockett, Burgan, and Wolfe. The
juniors chose: Haynes, Price,
Rogers, Belt, Weyforth, and Lloyd.
At a recent meeting of this board,
Rosenthal was elected editor-inchief; Haynes, assistant editor-inchief: Belt and Makel, business
managers; and Tappan, Stockett,
Burgan, Wolfe, Price, Rogers,
Veyforth. and Lloyd, associate editors. The board will hold regular
meetings every Wednesday night.
This is the first time that the
scheme of a joint publication of
the Hullabaloo has been tried by
senior and junior classes of normal
size. Two years ago there was a
joint book. But the reason for this
was that the junior class had only
nine or tell members and could not
possibly think of getting the book
out alone. The plan is a good one
and the result will be watched with
great interest.
A Declining Art.

Twenty years ago, when I was
an undergraduate, one of the
highest honors that could come to
a student was to be selected one
of a team to represent the college
in debate. I have observed that
this achievement brings little distinction to the undergraduate today
ill most institutions, which is to be
much regretted. The college world
is supposed to be the real world in
miniature. Certainly in this respect
it is not: for the world does recognize and gives its reward to the
man who can think quickly and
accurately and rise to his feet and
tell what he thinks. At Oxford the
student leaders win their spurs on
the floor of the Union. In this
country we find too frequently fatheaded football men who have no
other qualification than their brute
strength, flocked after sheep-like by
other students. It is a perverted
state of affairs.
E. PAIG AnDAms in College World.

The Track and Field Meet on Saturday

AI onager Hering of the 'varSity
track •teams and the captains and
managers of the sophomore and
freshman teams are working hard
to make the annual sophomorefreshman indoor track and field
meet to be held in the University
"cage" next Saturday surpass any
previous interclass meet that has
ver been held at Hopkins.
Owing to the limited seating capacity of the "cage" gallery, the
managers have decided to issue a
certain number of invitations which
will be distributed among the sophomores and freshmen. Only those
who have invitations will be admitted until the meet begins, and
then, if there is any space left,
it will.be a case ot first come first
served.
The old custom of having a silk
'banner as a trophy for the winning
class has been revived. This will be
embroidered with the numerals of
the victorious class and, as an everpresent reminder of its prowess in
track and field athletics, wil repose
on the walls of Levering Hall.
A distinctive feature of this
year's meet will be the relay race.
Although this event will not count
towards the winning of the meet,
it N arousing considerable interest
as an independent affair. The relay
teams will consist of four men, each
of whom will run three laps.
The freshmen will probably be
handicapped by the loss of their
captain who it at present laid up
with the mumps. There is a slight
possibility of his recovering in time
to take part, but his illness will prevent him from appearing at his best
even if he does compete, which is
not likely.
H. E. Catlin, the crack quarterback of the freshman football team
will act as captain during the illness,
of Wells. The freshmen have been
practicing regularly with the 'varsity squad and they will enter
quite a number of men.
Captain Ray, of the sophomores,
is quite optomistic in regard to the
outcome of the meet. He believes
that it will be close, but that the
sophomores will win by a few
points. In Ray, Pieper, and Novak,
thesophomores have some sure point
winners. and many of the other
sophomores' athletes have shown up
well so far in practice.
While the entries in the various
events will not be definitely known
until Thursday, Ray and Catlin

HARESFOOT CLUB TRYOUT
A Large Number of Candidates Respond
—The Cast To Be Definitely
Settled Next Week.

So many students wishing to
take part in the annual play of the
Haresfoot Club responded Tuesday
night in answer to the call for
candidates issued by N. Williams
Haynes, president of the club, that
two and three candidates had to be
assigned for the time being to each
of the 13 characters of the play.
Henry Edward \Varner, the wellknown local journalist, first president of the American Press
Humorists' Association and veteran
theatrical coach, will definitely
select the cast at the first rehearsal,
to be held some time. next week.
The club has also decided to have
an understudy for each character.
The play to be given is entitled
"What Happened to Jones." The
name will probably be changed, as
the play itself will be altered somewhat. The club is thinking of
offering a prize for the best name
submitted for the play. Several
out-of-town performances will be
given, and some time aiound Easter
the home performance will be given
at Albaugh's for the benefit of the
Homewood fund. Mty alumni
are already greatly interested in
the club and will work hard to
make this year's production a big
success.
Among • the candidates are: N.
W. Haynes, Frederick C. Lee,
Lindsay Rogers, Edward 0. Hulhurt, C. Leland Getz, Donald K.
Belt, Harold B. Hering, T. Brooke
Price, Paul 0. Carter, Edwin L.
Frederick, Alfred M. Randolph,
Mortimer McKeeney, Benjamin
Tappan, George C. Ober, Jr., J.
\Ale Stockett, G. G. Murray, Jr.,
Richard S. McCabe, and J. C. Martin.

The Baltimore Lacrosse League
held a meeting in the trophy room,
on Wednesday, to elect the officers
and make out the schedule for the
coming season.
The following officers were elected to serve for the following year:
President, John G. Hitck, J. H. U.;
Vice-President, George W. Gillett,
J. H. U.; Secretary, Edward Baker,
Mt. Washington; Treasurer, E. S.
Wiley, B. C. C.
The league consists of three
teams: Hopkins Scrubs, Mt. Washington Juniors, and Baltimore City
College. Last year some of the
alumni at Hopkins, who are great
lacrosse enthusiasts, chipped in and
bought a handsome cup for the
winning team; and for second
prize a beautiful banner was bought
by the league. The Mt. Washington Juniors came out first in the

Last Friday evening, the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs of the University gave a concert at the Music
Hall, Easton, Maryland, before a
large and fashionable audience.

by every one, especially the solo
by Mr. Ruth, and "Molly Lee" by

applause.

of the club attended an informal
dance, given for their benefit by the
young ladies of the town. They
were entertained Friday evening at
the houses of the various patronesses, and returned to the city on
the 9 o'clock train Saturday morning.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 23, 1911.

We regret that, owing to the
pressure of his work, Mr. T.
Brooke Price has been compelled to
resign as editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER. He will be much
missed, but we are glad to announce that we may retain him
on the board as a contributing
editor.
Other changes in the board and
new appointments were:
Lindsay Rogers, now managing
editor, to be assistant editor-inchief.
G. T. 0. Hollyday to be assistant
business manager.
George Edwin Dorsey to be
associate editor.

In the course of class work it
sometimes devolves upon us to do
some private reading in books
which are placed on reserved
shelves. The University cannot
supply each man with a copy and
the thirty or forty members of the
class must divide their time so that
each one has an opportunity to do
But prothe required reading.
crastination is an inevitable part of
human nature. The reading is
usually left • undone until a quizz
'is announced and then everyone
makes a rush for the books. At
such a time as this evil traits of
character at once manifest themselves in some students. In an unaccountable manner the books disappear. This is not so serious a
matter when there are five or six
copies on the shelves; but when
the book in question is a rare or
an expensive one it means that one
fellow sits at home and reads the
Look in his leisure time while the
others are frantically searching for
it. Two years ago an incident
occured which may illustrate this.
Some reading was required of a
class in a book which was out of
print and of which the library pos:
sessed only one copy. Shortly before the examination the book disappeared and several weeks later
reappeared in just as mysterious
a manner. Nothing was lost but
all the members of the class except
one were deprived of the use of the
book.
This is not the attitude of a true
university student. We should be
thankful for and appreciate the advantage which we enjoy in being
allowed free access to all books
in the library. Stich opportunities
should not be prostituted to greed
and selfishness, but should be used
so that all may receive the greatest
amount of good.

THE GYMNASIUM CONTESTS

NEW LACROSSE LISTS POSTED

ARBITRATION SOCIETY MEETS

CHESS TOURNAMENTS

Blues in the Lead—Hinrichs and Reilly
Big Point Winners.

A Different Method of Distributing Practice New Men Show Promise
of Good Work.

Talks Given by Members on Franklin,
Henry IV and Grotius.

Matches to be Arranged with University
of Pennsylvania and University of
Maryland—Freshman-Sophomore Match Probable.

The freshman gymnasium contest started off with a rush this
week. From the outset, both sides
were so enthusiastic that the entrants needed no urging from their
captains to be present. Besides the
ambition to win a medal, each
freshman wanted to do his part
toward breaking the records of last
year's contest. The gymnasium
class had been divided into two
sectfons, corresponding in ability, as
nearly as possible.
The captain .of the Blues is
Ceorge Dorsey; of the Whites,
Stewart White.
On Monday Professor Kistler
decided to open the contest. The
first event was the pull-up. One
point was given for each pull; in
that way every one could add at
least a few points to his side's
score.
Hinrichs (Whites) won first
place with seventeen to his credit.
Bryan (Whites) was second with
sixteen.
The second event was the standing high jump and Hinrichs again
won.
Although the Whites had made
174 point to their 162, in the first
day's work, the Blues determined
to struggle all the harder on Wednesday, caught up and passed the
Whites, much to the latter's
astonishment.
The score now was 215 to 214.
The records are as follows:
Pull-ups—This year, Hinrichs,
17; last year, H. H. Lloyd, 13.
Standing high jump—This year,
Hinrichs, 4 feet 2 inches; last year,
Kuehn, 5 feet 572 inches.
Fence vault—This year, Reilly,
5 feet 9 inches.
Standing broad jump—This year,
Reilly, 8 feet io inches; last year,
Hyland Stewart, 8 feet 9 inches.
Running high jump—This year,
White, 5 feet 72 inch; last year,
Hyland Stewart, 4 feet io% inches.

In spite of the fact that there
was some confusion about the
coaches, the prospects for a championship lacrosse team this year
are unusually bright. In the place
of Charlie Meyer, who was forced
to give up the position of head
coach on account of his graduate
work, Pitts Raleigh has taken
charge of the team. Coach Raleigh
played first defence on the team
last year, and is considered to be
one of the best close defence men
ever produced by Hopkins.
This year's captain, Eddie Hulbert, has adopted different tactics
from those used last year. He is
having the new men come out by
themselves on Wednesdays, instead
of only the best men as last year.
The whole squad is divided into
two sections, one of which practices
on Mondays and Thursdays, and
the other on Tuesdays and Fridays.
It is necessary to have the old men
in the squads, in order to teach the
new men the fine points of stick
work. On Saturdays there is a
scrimmage, which usually lasts for
about thirty-five minutes.
Since the Christmas holidays the
men have been working very hard,
and as a result they begin to show
a great improvement in condition.
The general opinion is that the new
tactics are better than the old, and
great results are expected.
The Tuesday and -Friday squad
consists of Stockett, Schmeisser,
Huck, Hopkins, J. Burgan, Rosenthal, Richardson, Herman,Simpson,
Hinrichs, Wilkens, Niles, Sears,
Makel, Simon, and Belt.
Dr. Abercrombie has permitted
the candidates for the Baltimore
City College lacrosse team the use
of the "cage" on Tuesdays and
Thursdays from three to four
o'clock. Stockett, Huck, and Gillet
are coaching the youngsters, and it
is hoped that under their able instruction they may some day turn
out to be good 'varsity men.
The regular Saturday squad consists of Stockett, Easter, Paulus,
Gail, Wolfe, Gillet, Hopkins, Niles,
Sutton, Huck, Price, Schmeisser,
Sears, Benedict, Everton, Wolman,
Randall, and Bridgman.

The Chess Club is showing that
it is a vital, living organization,
one that has come to stay and which
will add one more to the list of
permanent undergraduate activities.
The captain of the team, W. E.
Pearce, Jr., is in communication
with the chess club of the Univvsity of Pennsylvania and it is likely
that the date of the match will be
about the middle of February. It
is to be a six-board match.
At a meeting of the executive
committee on Friday the challenge
of the City College to the freshman
team was considered. As there is
no freshman team here it was proposed to make up a seven-man team
from the players in the minor tournament to play the City College
team. A committee of one was appointed to confer with the captain
of the City College team and
arrange a date.
Recently.a chess club was formed
at the University of Maryland and
it was expected that the Hopkins
team would receive a challenge from
them. But this challenge has not
come. So the captain of the Hopkins team was instructed to send
a challenge to the University of
Maryland team for an eight-board
match to be played either on the 3d,
4th, or ioth of February. It is
desired to have several matches
before the team goes to Philadelphia to play the strong team of
the Pennsylvania University and so
it is necessary that these matches
be played as soon as possible.
All but five games of the minor
tournament have been played. The
tournament was to have come to a
close on the 21st of January but
the executive committee voted to
extend this time two weeks.
It has been proposed to the freshman and sophomore classes to have
an interclass chess match. Such
a match would add another to the
list of contests between the classes
and would arouse great interest.
This question will be voted on by
both classes this week and the
teams will be chosen as soon as possible.

President Wilmer Ray, of the
sophomore class has appointed the
committee to arrange the annual
class banquet. It consists of C.
Leland Getz, chairman, Emory H.
Niles, C. Ellis Ellicott, and President Ray, ex-officio.

"Good Old Mantuan."

The Classical Club of the Johns
Hopkins University met last evening at 614 N. Howard street, on
invitation of Dr. W.E. Moseley. Dr.
Wilfred Mustard, collegiate professor of Latin, read an interesting
paper on "The Eclogues of Baptista
Mantuanus."
These were ten Latin poems
written in the second half of the
fifteenth century, and first printed
in the year 1498. They were immediately provided with a commentary, by a well-known scholar,
Badius Ascensius ; and for nearly
two hundred years they were very
commonly used, both on the Continent and in England, as a text-book
in schools. And they had a very
considerable influence upon 'European literature of the sixteenth
century.
The author was a Carmelite friar
of Mantua, who afterwards rose to
be general of his order. He was
beatified in 1885. His works were
very popular, and he was hailed
by many of his contemporaries as
a second Virgil. He is often quoted
in Elizabethan writers—for example, in Shakespeare's "Love's
Labours Lost." And his Eclogues
were very frequently imitated, the
most important instance being
Spenser's "Shepherd's Calendar."

The second general meeting of
the Arbitration Society was held
in the Donovan Room Wednesday
afternoon at three o'clock.
President Bobbitt opened the
meeting with a brief review of the
progress which has been made in
interesting the schools and colleges
of the country in the peace movement, and stated that the Arbitration Society at Hopkins, being the
first institution of the kind ever
organized, it would, if successful,
probably serve as a model for
future orgaizations.
Brief talks were then given by
various members of the society on
early labourers toward universal
peace. Mr. Lindsay Rogers discussing Benjamin Franklin, Mr.
J. E. Uhler, Henry of Navarre, and
Mr. J. S. Dickinson, Hugo Grotius.
A motion was carried that henceforth the society hold a general
meeting once every two weeks, and
the president was instructed to appoint a committee of three on programs.

The Speech for .Special Occasions,'
edited by Ella A. Knapp, Ph, D., Associate Professor of Rhetoric in Goucher
College, and John C. French, Ph. D.,
Associate in English in the Johns Hopkins University. The Macmillan Company. Price. $1.10 net.

This volume of occasional speeches, prepared by Professor Knapp
and Dr. French, is intended to supply a need which has come to the
attention of the authors in their
own teaching. It is intended to
afford the college student a collection of the best speeches delivered upon such occasions as are
likely to confront him in his own
career.
Consequently in these
pages we meet none of the timehonored models of forensic or parliamentary eloquence. Henry May
is represented not by the closing
passage of his speech on the Greek
Revolution nor on the Expunging
Resolution, but by a few simple
and courteous words of welcome to
Lafayette. Daniel Webster contributes, not the peroration of the Reply
to Hague, but a humble effort addressed to the Royal Agricultural
Society of England. The collection
is intended not merely as a textbook, but also as a manual for the
general reader, to which he may
turn for assistance when confronted
by that most embarassing of all
requests, the invitation to make a
speech. For this purpose the selections are classified according to
the nature of the occasion upon
which they were delivered. Thus
there are "Speeches in Behalf of
a Cause," "Speeches of a President," "Speeches of Welcome,"
"Speeches of Farewell," etc.
The selections, which were for
the most part chosen by Professor
Knapp are, on the whole, quite
appropriate. Because of the very
nature of the book, there are but
few from the works of the world's
great orators and most are taken
from the sincere and informal utterances of scholars and statesmen of
the past half century—men like
Bancroft, Emerson, Bryant, Root,
and Gildersleeve. It might seem,
therefore, a matter for curiosity
how a quaint and time-mellowed
,peech of Queen Elizabeth came to
find its way into such company.
Dr. French contributes an introduction of thirty-three pages, in
which he sets forth briefly and concisely the principles following
which a speech may be most effectivelr composed and delivered.

friend of peace, he refused all the

which is called "The Folly of
Building Temples of Peace with
Untempered Mortar" (New York:
B. W. Huebsch), he states his
reasons for believing that the only
solution of the problem of international peace is the abolition of
all protective tariffs.
He says that the peace advocates
do not realize that "since our own
Civil War there has been a yet
more flagrant war raging in our
own country, a war annually becoming more menacing and disastrous. It is not a civil war only,
but a foreign war as well; a war not
against one nation only; but against
all commercial nations. It is a domestic as well as universal foreign
war to enforce our preposterous
claim to an average half of what any
foreign shipper brings to our
ports."
Then the author follows with a
detailed statement of all the wellknown objections to and arguments
against a protective tariff and say
that it is not only economicay
false but is unconstitutional and immoral.
Not content with outlining his
reason for the failure, as he calls
it, of peace to be more universal,
and war to be relegated to the background, Mr. Bigelow offers a solution of the problem in a second
half, of the work which he
calls; "The Necessity of Building
Temples of Peace with Tempered
Mortar." Here he outlines a new
revenue system for the United
States, which would be necessary
if a return to the free trade policy
were adopted.
Governmental partnership in
public utilities, important inventions, and copyrighted books are
only some of the things which he
suggests. He says that he has long
been an advocate of the retention
by Congress of an interest in the
natural resources of the country
before they are given over to private hands, and by a series of interesting calculations he shows what
the returns would have been if this
policy had been adopted.
Each reader will have to accept
the book and its theories, some of
them revolutionary, for just what
he thinks them worth. After all,
the whole question is whether the
United States and other nations
would be justified in returning to
a free trade policy, but the question
of whether a tariff is a vital hindrance to perpetual peace and the
settlement of international differences without resort to the arbitrament of the sword is another
matter, for which Mr. Bigelow
makes out a fairly convincing case.
The book ought to be of great,
interest to the members of the Hopkins Arbitration Society who are

COMMUNICATIONS

is always glad to

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.
I notice that the football management has scheduled a game with the
Navy on October 7th. Permit me
to register a protest against this apparent foolhardiness. Our team
never reaches the height of its capability until the season is half completed; the late opening of the University, the consequent lateness of
beginning of practice, the impossibility of getting out the Medical
School men in .the first weeks, all
contribute to make our team at this
time a mere shadow of what it will
become later. By hard work we
have reached the standard of big
college teams. We have been allowed an opportunity to show if we
can hold to this standard. The
Navy has said: "You have boasted
so much that we'll give you a
chance. Let's see what you can
do." In return, we shall play them
with practically the weakest team
that we can put on the field. Nothing will contribute so surely to send
us back to the rank of small colleges
as a failure to make a good showing
against the Navy. And who can be
idiotic enough to claim that we
shall make a good showing? In our
first game last year we were tied
by the Maryland Agricultural College; in our first game this year
what will not the Navy do to us?
Our pretensions to higher standing
will become a pretense. Mr.- Yellott
will grin for a whole week. We
shall not have the opportunity to do
justice to ourselves that a later
game would afford.
INDIGNATION PERSONIPIED.
The Tocqueville Medal.

HULLABALOO BOARD ORGANIZES
-Rosenthal Elected Editor-in-Chief—Belt
and Makel Business- Managers.

The question of publishing the
year book for 1911, the Hullabaloo,
has at last been settled. Owing to
the failure of the junior class to
publish it last year, there was a
great deal of controversy as to who
should publish it this year, the present junior class or the senior class.
It was finally decided to get out a
joint book, each class choosing six
representatives. The senior class
elected: Rosenthal, Tappan, Makel,
Stockett, Burgan, and Wolfe. The
juniors chose: Haynes, Price,
Rogers, Belt, Weyforth, and Lloyd.
At a recent meeting of this board,
Rosenthal was elected editor-inchief; Haynes, assistant editor-inchief: Belt and Makel, business
managers; and Tappan, Stockett,
Burgan, Wolfe, Price, Rogers,
Veyforth. and Lloyd, associate editors. The board will hold regular
meetings every Wednesday night.
This is the first time that the
scheme of a joint publication of
the Hullabaloo has been tried by
senior and junior classes of normal
size. Two years ago there was a
joint book. But the reason for this
was that the junior class had only
nine or tell members and could not
possibly think of getting the book
out alone. The plan is a good one
and the result will be watched with
great interest.
A Declining Art.

Twenty years ago, when I was
an undergraduate, one of the
highest honors that could come to
a student was to be selected one
of a team to represent the college
in debate. I have observed that
this achievement brings little distinction to the undergraduate today
ill most institutions, which is to be
much regretted. The college world
is supposed to be the real world in
miniature. Certainly in this respect
it is not: for the world does recognize and gives its reward to the
man who can think quickly and
accurately and rise to his feet and
tell what he thinks. At Oxford the
student leaders win their spurs on
the floor of the Union. In this
country we find too frequently fatheaded football men who have no
other qualification than their brute
strength, flocked after sheep-like by
other students. It is a perverted
state of affairs.
E. PAIG AnDAms in College World.

Regulations respecting the essay
for the Tocqueville Medal have
been published on the bulletin
board. This medal is given annually for the best essay on some
phase of French history between
1815 and 1890 or for a review of
some important historical work
published in France since 1891.
The essay must be between 8,000
and 16,000 words in length.
The medal is given in honor of
Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-59)
author of the well-known historical
and political studies -Ancien Regime" and "Democratic en Amerique." The winner of the medal
